entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 10 at 5:36AM CDT by NWS San Angelo TX
entry.summary:

SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.

This includes Interstate 10 between Mile Markers 343 and 417.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued June 10 at 5:33AM CDT until June 11 at 10:36AM CDT by NWS Topeka KS
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Kansas...
Neosho River Near Neosho Rapids affecting Lyon County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Neosho River near Neosho Rapids.
* WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning.
* IMPACTS...At 22.0 feet, Low lying areas along the river flood. At 23.0 feet, Water overtops Road 145 on the west side of the bridge over the Neosho River.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:30 AM CDT Tuesday the stage was 22.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this afternoon and continue falling to 17.4 feet Saturday evening. - Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lyon, KS

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW MORNING

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued June 10 at 5:06AM CDT until June 10 at 8:15AM CDT by NWS San Angelo TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of west central Texas, including the following counties, Crockett, Irion, Schleicher and Tom Green.
* WHEN...Until 815 AM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 505 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 0.75 and 1.25 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 0.75 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Mertzon, Sherwood, Barnhart, Arden, Us-190 Near The Crockett- Sutton County Line and Us-67 Near The Irion-Tom Green County Line. - This includes the following Low Water Crossings... RM 853 crossing Dry Draw, Ranch Road 853 crossing east Rocky Creek, Ranch Road 859 crossing west Rocky Creek, Ranch Road 853 crossing Middle Concho River, County Road 113 crossing Dove Creek, crossings along County Road 411, crossings along County Road 302, County Road 202 crossing Lopez Creek, Sherwood Cemetery crossing and County Road 202 crossing Spring Creek. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Crockett, TX; Irion, TX; Schleicher, TX; Tom Green, TX

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 10 at 5:44AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
Areas of fog have developed across the region. There is some patchy dense fog where visibilities have been reduced to near a half to quarter of a mile.
Motorists should be aware of rapidly changing visibilities and proceed with extra caution. Use low beam headlights, reduce speeds, and leave extra distance between yourself and the vehicle in front of you.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued June 10 at 4:15AM EDT until June 10 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents and strong longshore currents in the surf zone.
* WHERE...For the high rip current threat, the beaches from Cape Hatteras to Bogue Inlet. For the longshore currents, beaches from Cape Hatteras to Cape Lookout and beaches from Beaufort Inlet to Bogue Inlet.
* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 1:20 PM Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: West Carteret; East Carteret; Ocracoke Island; Hatteras Island

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 10 at 3:48AM EDT by NWS Louisville KY
entry.summary:
The combination of clearing skies, light winds, and wet ground has led to the develop of locally dense fog across portions of central Kentucky this morning. The fog will be most dense in low-lying areas and near bodies of water. Motorists should exercise caution and be prepared for quickly changes in visibility over short distances.
The fog will mix out after sunrise. Stay tuned to NOAA all hazards weather radio and your local media for the latest updates.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued June 10 at 2:47AM CDT by NWS Tulsa OK
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Tulsa has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in Arkansas...
Arkansas River at Ozark Lock and Dam affecting Franklin, Logan and Johnson Counties.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Arkansas River at Ozark Lock and Dam.
* WHEN...From early this morning until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 357.0 feet, flooding affects agricultural use lands along the river downstream of the lock and dam in Franklin County. Gas fields are also subject to flooding downstream. Equipment and livestock should be moved to higher ground. North 5th Street in Logan County near the Six Mile Levee begins to flood and may cut off access to a nearby residence.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:00 AM CDT Tuesday the stage was 356.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to near 354.0 feet by this evening and remain below flood stage. The river is then forecast to rise and fluctuate between 355.0 and 357.0 feet beginning Wednesday evening and continue at these levels until further notice. - Action stage is 355.5 feet. - Flood stage is 357.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Franklin, AR; Johnson, AR; Logan, AR

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM EARLY THIS MORNING UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 9 at 10:42PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: High pressure builds across the Interior as we experience a large scale pattern change. Temperatures in Interior valleys warm rapidly through the week with highs rising to the mid to upper 60s Tuesday, the upper 60s to lower 70s Wednesday, the mid 70s Thursday, and upper 70s Friday. Temperatures this weekend may reach into the lower 80s.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued June 9 at 11:31PM PDT until June 10 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
...BREEZY WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY EXPECTED TODAY AND TUESDAY...
.Winds are expected to increase through the Kittitas Valley, Columbia River Gorge, and into the Columbia Basin again in the afternoon Tuesday. This, combined with very low RHs due to the ongoing heat wave, will make for increased risks for wildfire spread, especially during the afternoon and early evening hours Tuesday.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 690 Kittitas Valley and 691 Lower Columbia Basin of Washington.
* TIMING...Until 8 PM PDT Tuesday.
* WINDS...West 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 10 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fire that develops will catch and spread quickly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kittitas Valley; Lower Columbia Basin

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM PDT TUESDAY FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES WA690 AND WA691

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued June 9 at 9:22PM PDT until June 10 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
...HOT, DRY, AND BREEZY TUESDAY...
.Fire weather conditions have risen above critical thresholds Monday evening. Afternoon Cascade gap winds will develop again Tuesday afternoon across central Washington with hot temperatures in the 80s and 90s and dry conditions.
* Affected Area: Fire Weather Zone 705 Foothills of Central Washington Cascades (Zone 705) and Fire Weather Zone 706 Waterville Plateau (Zone 706).
* Winds: Northwest 10 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* Relative Humidities: 10 to 20 percent.
* Impacts: Risk of rapidly spreading fires.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Washington Cascade Foothills; Waterville Plateau

entry.summary:
An Air Quality Advisory for ground level fine particles has been issued by the Northeast Ohio Areawide Coordinating Agency for Ashtabula, Cuyahoga, Geauga, Lake, Lorain, Medina, Portage and Summit Counties.
The advisory is from midnight tonight to midnight Tuesday night.
Air quality levels will be unhealthy for sensitive groups during this period. If you are in the sensitive groups category of children, the elderly and those with breathing difficulties, please monitor your outdoor activity and check air quality readings at airnow.gov. Additionally, sign-up at enviroflash.info for text alerts regarding air quality.
To help our region reduce air pollution:
* Drive less: bike, walk, use transit, work from home, combine trips * Visit gohiocommute.com/noaca - Find a smarter way to travel! * Don't idle - Turn off your engine * Refill your tank after sunset * Wait to mow the lawn

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued June 9 at 9:29AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
AQAPSR
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued an Ozone High Pollution Advisory for the Phoenix Metro Area on Tuesday.
This means that forecast weather conditions combined with existing ozone levels are expected to result in local maximum 8-hour ozone concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Ozone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties for children, older adults, as well as persons with respiratory problems. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
You are urged to car pool, telecommute or use mass transit. The use of gasoline-powered equipment should be reduced or done late in the day.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/phoenix or call 602-771-2300.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Maricopa, AZ

cap:parameter.value: OZONE HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR MARICOPA COUNTY INCLUDING THE PHOENIX METRO AREA TUESDAY
